displayed_text: Doctor: Hi. How are you? Doctor: You’re in pain. Why don’t you go and talk to your girlfriend and get your pain medicine from her? Patient: I’ve can’t did that. Doctor: You what? Patient: It ain’t no girlfriend. Doctor: Or whoever that was. The woman. Patient: So that be ah ah the police looking for her and now they found and press charges. I don’t know her number. I don’t want her around me. I want nobody around me no more. Doctor: hhh Okay because… Patient: I don’t want no one… Doctor: …you know what the pharmacist said now. Patient: Yes I’ve been going to H_____. Doctor: So you’re going to H_____ Pharmacy now? Patient: Yeah.

Patient: And I have I mean it’s a fact. But that one time was bad so then I just had it um (pause) Doctor: Okay. Yeah Patient: Two weeks ago today and it wasn’t nearly as bad. Doctor: Okay. Patient: But it’s also not seeming to work like it did. Doctor: Yeah, yeah. I hear the PSA is starting to creep up a little. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Ours isn’t back yet, but his is going up. Patient: Yeah I mean I… Doctor: Mhmm Patient: I think I started chemo and I was in the low thirties. I went down in to twenties and I’m back up to thirty I think the last one from B______. Doctor: Yeah. Okay. You know the lymph nodes are starting to grow again. Just plumpier um Patient: I had a CT scan

Patient: Okay. Is that the – Doctor: Xtandi. Patient: Xtandi. Okay. That was a shot once a month or? Doctor: That was the pills you were taking. Patient: Oh, I did take them. Yeah. Okay. Doctor: So that would say if we did that just as a course of action and the likelihood it’s gonna help you is pretty low. Patient: Oh. Doctor: And so, this study is looking at a new therapy –uh, the hottest new drugs that are out there, and when we’ve given them to men with prostate cancer, we haven’t seen a whole lot. (Pause) Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Um. And the two drugs together, uh, may be, uh, cause responses. Uh, but we don’t know. And that’s why we’re doing a research study. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And we’re giving folks who’ve got bad disease this because the worry is these drugs may have a lot of side effects. Most of the time, they’re tolerated well, but what they do is they turn on your immune system, hope that your immune system is going to attack your cancer, but I also could turn on your immune system with these medicines and it attacks you. Okay? So you can get a pneumonia that’s from your immune system. You can get hepatitis because it’s attacking your liver. You could get colitis ‘cuz it’s attacking your colon. Uh, it usually picks one organ, not not all of ‘em, but, you know, you can get into trouble because your immune system – while it’s tryin’ to fight your cancer, it’s tryin’ to fight you. Uh. And when we Patient: I see. This is from the – both the uh– the, uh, both of the –

Patient: Four. Doctor: Argh! I can’t even trip him off. Family Member: I know. I know. Doctor: Well… you might need chemo. Let me say that again. You might need chemo. Was that whiney enough for you? Family Member: Yeah. Well, at least you have something. You could’ve came in here and said, “Oh, we got nothing for you. Doctor: Oh no, I got tons of stuff for you. The question is when and how and how do you feel about that. Family Member: S___? Patient: I can live with it if I can do the infusion stuff up there. Doctor: Okay. That's a possibility. However, as anything else, we actually have a study. Half the group gets regular chemo, which is IV. The other group gets a pill chemo which is oral. I can't tell you which one you are. And of course, we need you to commit so that if you say there's no freakin way I'm gonna get chemo down here then don't do the trial, but it's a fifty-fifty Family Member: You don't want to come down here xxx do you? Patient: How often do I have to be here? Doctor: Well, chemo is once every three weeks. So if you're good, don't quote me because I botched up a thousand things today in terms of the schedule, which is why I keep my mouth shut half the time. But standard chemo is once every three weeks. Family Member: Oh that’s not too bad.

Patient: Probably a program. Doctor: ‘Cuz we would put the prescription into our pharmacy. We would have them figure out how much it’s gonna cost you, and then if it’s too much, they could start looking for these plans that they cover the cost for you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And if that’s so, then it would be cheap. Then you would be taking a drug that I don’t think is gonna work with the idea that I need you to be on this drug so that the immune therapy might work which is research, experimental, unsure. Okay? Family Member: Is there any way on the portal – his daughter wants to keep up what’s, what’s going over -- like what we said today. Does she have your power of something? Have some way that she can check on, uh – like MyLGHHealth, I can go in there and see, read everything, and results and that. Doctor: Yeah, I mean, he is active on MyChart. That’s where I wrote you that note. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So he can let her – Family Member: Okay. Doctor: He can give her the password. The system doesn’t know who’s looking. You know, but it is his password. Family Member: Right. Okay. Doctor: Okay? But you need to be able to call her or talk to her or you have to sign forms out front to give me release. Okay?

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, So, it is also an infusion, and I’ll have to pull it up. Uh, I don’t know how often you have to be there, but it – there is a slot available. It says that, uh, it has to be people with bone disease only. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Um, they used to say that you had to have only Abiraterone or Enzalutamide. Uh, but now, they have broadened it, that if you have had Abiraterone AND Enzalutamide, you can participate. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. So, that one would be an option for you. Um. It’s uncharted territory. Patient: No chemo drug, though? Doctor: It is more of a natural product, biologic drug that on, um, in animals and in cell lines looks active against prostate cancer. And, so, now they’re escalating the dose of this natural product. Um. Family Member: Is that, uh, a stem cell or cell therapy or is it a -- Doctor: No, it comes like from a, I--I’d have to look. Whether it comes from a seed cucumber or-- Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Or a pine co—Oh, it’s—I’d have to look it up. But, it’s, it’s a natural thing that, that, they have --- Patient: It’s organic medicine.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And to be together. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So everything we’ve done so far is to try to keep the ball away from the glove. (Beeping) Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The cancer sometimes will evolve a form of the glove that doesn’t need a ball. It, it still works. Patient: I see. Doctor: All the things it does downstream without the ball. We’ve been testing that as part of this trial. So I need to dig into the group that’s testing and find out are you one of those guys that was positive? Patient: Okay. Doctor: If you were positive, that would mean pretty strongly that we shouldn’t try more hormone treatments. You need to be positive for that to go on this immune trial. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh they’re looking for folks who might have more aggressive hormone insensitive cases. So I’m, I’m going to do that this week just to find out.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.5-9 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::5-9 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.strongly agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::strongly agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Unemployed for less than 1 year: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Unemployed for less than 1 year
Which of the following best describe you.Student: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Student

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Then they mail it to your house Patient: Okay. Doctor: and then when you get it you take four pills a day. Patient: Mm, Hmm. Doctor: If you can, you just call us, call K__ or W__ and go hey we got the medicine Patient: Right. Doctor: that way I know when you started. When you’ve been on it for two or three weeks, you come back to see me and we’ll make sure you’re doing okay. Patient: When I’m doing okay. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: So now okay you know what my next question is… Doctor: Yeah. Patient: You know I got that motorcycle.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But more concerning is just you have more lymph nodes or they’re not even technically lymph nodes they’re more… Patient: Nodules. Doctor: …nodules in the belly whereas before… Doctor: Yeah. It’s more of the schmutz that we talked about… Patient: Um hum. Doctor: …that was hard to characterize. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: That schmutz has sort of formalized more into you can call them a nodule, a mass… Patient: Mass. Doctor: …a thingy, a whatever it is, but it’s the cancer. Patient: Mass.

Patient: I was just checking. Doctor: What is it? Patient: I was just checking. Family Member: Do you have any- Doctor: That is like, I’m going to shoot you. I’ll be right back. Okay boss. Patient: I was just checking. Doctor: You had to scare me like that. I have no idea. Family Member: I just gave him some M and M’s. Good thing I brought them in. Not M and M’s but Good and Plenty. Doctor: Why you running so low? Family Member: He ate breakfast but he didn’t eat it all at the restaurant. Patient: I was just checking. Family Member: He had an omelet and toast and .

Family Member: Every time you go there I mean you can’t get in to see him. I mean you’re there for hours. Doctor: I B___ City? Patient: B___ City, yeah. Family Member: Yes. Patient: Yeah, yeah. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So… Patient: So yeah I’d rather see somebody… Family Member: We burned that bridge. Patient: I’d rather see somebody… yeah can’t go back to that. Doctor: I know because honestly then maybe and that probably should get fixed – Family Member: Yes. Doctor: - even if we make decisions about chemotherapy or something we cannot afford to have a major source of infection sitting right there. So definitely that will hold up a lot of our decisions about other treatments for sure.

Patient: You know, I feel good. Doctor: That’s good. Let’s see and you’re sixty… Patient: No I’m fifty-nine. Doctor: Fifty-nine. Patient: I’m not sixty yet. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: It’s alright. (laughs) Doctor: Fifty-nine. And generally men under sixty have a recurrence I mean are able to have a sexual function even without medication ultimately. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: So I suspect that you’ll probably be there. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright? It’s still early.

Patient: You know I’m not trying to underestimate anything you know and you know because I never felt you know from the beginning I never felt… Doctor: Felt any symptoms. Patient: Yes. You know. Doctor: I understand. Neither did I. So we’ll get you to see Dr. R____ as soon as possible and I’ll see you back in three months. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And you get your blood test before you come back. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Sound good? Patient: Thank you again. Doctor: Tell them before the end of July because I’m taking off June and July I’m having hip surgery. Patient: Oh okay. Doctor: So I’ll be seeing you though towards the end of July. Okay?

Family Member: And then you eat breakfast. Patient: And then I’ll get up again and check it again. Doctor: Alright. Yeah. I think you could get off the carbs. Family Member: Right. Doctor: It would be better. That’s all. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Right. Just quit getting – we can’t have spaghetti for Father’s Day. Doctor: No. You can have squash spaghetti. Family Member: Yeah. I could see my daughter-in-law making that. (Laughter) Doctor: I’m just saying, you can have spaghetti, just not pasta. Family Member: Pasta. Right. Not cereal. We need to get rid of the Special K. Doctor: No cereal. No bread. No pasta.

Family Member: Tired. Doctor: I know it’s been long. Thanks for your patience. Um sit over here. Patient: Sure. Family Member: Sure. Doctor: I know I’m going to take you away from your wife but I’d rather we look at each other than my back. Patient: Yeah, sure. Doctor: Blood pressure’s a little high today. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Is that wrong for you or you just came in rushing? Patient: No, no, it’s usually pretty good, about one forty, one fifty at the highest. So that is a little high, yeah. Doctor: Are you taking Ondansetron? That’s for nausea. Patient: Uh occasionally, not as much as I did when I was going through radiation. Doctor: So occasionally, like once a week, once a month?
